awd_titl_txt: Planning Grant: Engineering Research Center for Intelligent Infrastructure for Safe, Efficient and Resilient Mobility (ERC-I2SERM)
awd_abstract_narration:
The Planning Grants for Engineering Research Centers competition was run as a pilot solicitation within the ERC program.  Planning grants are not required as part of the full ERC competition, but intended to build capacity among teams to plan for convergent, center-scale engineering research.

This planning grant award supports the design of an Engineering Research Center (ERC) focused upon potentially transformative science and engineering research that promises to make our roadways safer, more reliable, more efficient, and more environmentally sustainable. This research will stimulate the transformation of the way we travel and deliver goods and services.  Roadways and highways are not only national economic lifelines but impact every sphere of societal activities.  Next generation transportation infrastructure must have sufficient capacity, making it able to grow with the increasing demand and address the emerging connected, automated and shared vehicle technologies. It should also be resistant to interruptions, able to withstand all manner of regional natural hazards. Finally, it must be aesthetic, have negligible environmental impact, and use minimal resources.  These interrelated demands present an opportunity for a new era of intelligent transportation infrastructure based on new materials, sensing and automation, and greater interactions with the world.  We imagine future highway and roadway systems which extensively utilize cutting-edge (smart) materials, smart and adaptable infrastructure, smart transportation systems and physics-guided data science to achieve safety, resiliency, and efficiency.  Such an intelligent infrastructure will be able to sense, interpret and interact in real time with its environment. This allows for anticipation and adjustment to external stimuli, such as those posed by traffic and extreme events.  The planning grant activities will provide the platform for identification of key technical challenges, their potential solution hypotheses, and the disciplinary contributions that will lead to formation of the most effective ERC. 

To identify key technical challenges to resilient transportation infrastructure, the planning team will engage deeply with stakeholders and domain experts. This will be done through a dedicated workshop, panel discussion(s) and a team building retreat.  The results of these engagements will form the basis for fine tuning the technical topics and coordination of the research agenda across the core areas and to define the linkages among the disciplines.  The expected outcome will be identification of a set of critical research issues and a broad yet convergent research program. This allows for a clear definition of the structure and roles within this envisioned multi-university center. These planning activities will also define the ways the center will be able to represent diverse institutions from the viewpoint of geography, types of students served (including minority students) as well as their location in or near major metropolitan areas.  The planned stakeholder engagement, workshop, and retreat are expected to impact the outlook of academic investigators towards these societal challenges, as well as how the stakeholders (e.g., industrial innovators, policymakers, citizens) perceive scientific research.  The planning activities will also engage graduate and undergraduate students to provide them exposure to emerging transdisciplinary research opportunities.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Mobility and accessibility are fundamental societal and civic needs. Achieving equitable mobility and accessibility is challenging due to the long-standing spatial mismatch between locations of residences and activities such as work, healthcare, school, etc. The key societal grand challenge that this planning grant addressed is that of mobility and accessibility. Efficient road infrastructure is essential for all human activities, including access to jobs, education, healthcare etc. A re-imagination of road infrastructure must evaluate needs and choices, and the impact of each choice on mobility. As a goal, such an effort must ensure that reimagined infrastructure improves accessibility, community resilience, environmental sustainability, and reduces geographical imbalance between employment and affordable housing. 

Road infrastructure has a central role in mobility and accessibility whether it is the need to connect jobs to housing, deliver goods and services to communities, or provide evacuation and emergency services during extreme events and disasters. Roadways and highways are important for fulfilling the need for transportation of goods and people over long-distances. Roads have an even more significant role in connecting communities, contributing to their resiliency and providing the last-mile accessibility. They are national economic lifelines and influence every sphere of societal endeavors. Even in one-off pandemic events, such as the current COVID-19 disruptions, which resulted in lockdowns, work-from-home and reduction of vehicular traffic and utilization of public transportation, the centrality of roadways remained for transportation of essential services and goods (e.g. food, perishables). Whether such one-off events will affect the total miles travelled in the future is difficult to predict, nevertheless, it is clear that road transportations will remain an important component of economic resilience. 

In the United States, road infrastructure is in critical need for preventive maintenance and upgradation. Next generation transportation infrastructure must have sufficient capacity, should be able to accommodate the increasing demand; be resistant to interruptions; should address the emerging connected, automated, and shared vehicles; should be able to withstand all manner of regional natural hazards; must be aesthetic; have negligible environmental impact; and use minimal resources. These interrelated demands present an opportunity for a new era of intelligent transportation infrastructure based upon new materials, sensing and automation, and greater interconnectivity. This vision challenges the tradition of building passive infrastructure. 

Based upon the project activities that included workshops and team building engagement with a range of stakeholders from private, public, and academic sectors, the overall convergence research approach can be organized into three categories: (1) Social Science and Intelligent Road System (2) Metamaterials and Smart Structures; and (3) Data Science (e.g., Big Data, Machine Learning, Deep Learning). Recent breakthroughs in Data Science, engineering including the development in metamaterials, smart and intelligent transportation systems, as well as the wide-ranging studies in social science related to needs and access have the promise to help address societal grand challenges in mobility. It is clear that there is a need for both cutting-edge innovative technology and enabling policies. 

The project discussion and feedback from the stakeholders clearly shows that the stage is ripe for a deep analysis of the strengths and weaknesses of these innovations as well as the obstacles and threats (SWOT), particularly in light of the highly regulated nature of transportation, which features high liability for failures and high costs and financing. Often the focus is on the renewal of existing road infrastructure through incremental fixes; however, such efforts fail to exploit the cutting edge of knowledge. A center engaged in research, development of cutting-edge applicable science and technology in road transportation would contribute in bridging the gap between what is required, and what is possible. Examples of questions that such a center could address include, how can pedestrians, bicyclists, automobiles sharing the road, and sense each other at intersections, during adverse weather conditions? Where should the communications, power supply, sensors reside? Is the road completely passive? If yes then how does it communicate its condition? if active then how? What are the barriers in adoption of new technologies?   Such a center will function as a catalyst for transferring new science-based solutions to practice at a faster pace than at the present. 

The time is also ripe for confronting the nation's roadway infrastructure challenges in the presence of the pulls (renew aging infrastructure and Federal interest) and pushes (disruptive technologies such as connected and automated vehicles (CAVs)). Many communities are investing to renew and to improve resilience to address increasingly extreme climate effects. The impending use of CAVs in our nation will reshape our cities and transform how infrastructure serves our people. At the same time, there is opportunity due to emerging AI, data science, cyber-physical systems, autonomous vehicle investments, additive manufacturing and metamaterials. There is also keen federal interest for innovative approaches to infrastructure R&D and construction.
